One of the greatest singleplayer and puzzle games of all time. There's phenomenal character development as well as storytelling and the puzzles are JUST hard enough to be satisfying. Not too easy, not too hard, extremely creative and exciting. Wonderful game and it still holds up today.

Portal 2 came out in 2011, and is the continuation of the smash hit "Portal" from 2007. The game sees a return to the world of Aperture Science, once again through the the eyes of the test subject "Chell". This time, however, many years has passed. Aperture Science is [i]years[/i] passed its peak of operations, and is overrun with vast amounts of flora. 

I [i]love[/i] this game. This version of Aperture Science's testing facility is simply fascinating. Valve captured the feeling of the building being seemingly [i]alive[/i], like its a whole character in and of itself. Throughout the game you'll see familiar parts of the lab and completely new areas, all with an air of mystique clouding the room. The testing facility, for lack of a better word, has an "electricity" to it. Every scene showcasing it just feels masterfully crafted. It ends up feeling sort of like Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory in a way. 

The testing chambers and puzzles are excellent. Valve put the perfect amount of both easy and simple chambers, right alongside the hard and challenging ones. The end result is a game with great flow to it; its easy to get lost in the game, spending hours in one play through, as it doesn't just feel like a bunch of puzzles pieced together to form a game. Rather instead, it feels like you are constantly moving forward into the heart of Aperture Science, going on a genuine storytelling journey. Similarly, the pacing throughout the game is damn near perfect. It'll feel like the puzzles start out easy, get increasingly challenging, and then just when it starts to begin to get too hard or complicated, another puzzle element will be introduced and the cycle restarts at easy, or a plot point will move onward and the story takes over, often times meaning you get to journey into the behind the scenes of Aperture Science for a quick breather.

Adding on to this, you get to see vast amounts of the surreal factory-like behind the scenes of Aperture Science. This is brilliantly realized. Various moments of the game have fantastic, beautiful set pieces that make you drop your jaw, or go "damn thats actually interesting".
